comments.text:
It is also a sad thing farmers care more about profits than human life.  It 
is also a sad thing people who make cars, clothes, houses, paper, music, 
and every single fucking thing around you, care more about profits than 
human life.

What do you get as a result of this?  Human life.....  This is what happens 
when everybody lives for themselves.  Its hard to wrap your head around it, 
but selfishness is a lot better than selflessness in so many ways.

1. Who takes the best care of you?

2. Who understands your wants and desires the most?

3. Who knows what you want to do in the future?

and so forth and so forth.....

You quickly come to the conclusion that it is yourself that is the answer 
to all of these.  Once you understand this, you will understand why 
everything is for profit and not for "human life" other than the occasional 
non-profit organizations that are horribly inefficient.

comments.author: MrTopGunnar

comments.text:
+MrTopGunnar Do you seriously not see the difference? Drug companies are in 
the position to cure diseases, I am not. And why would I have to move to 
Africa? What on earth has that got to do with this? And guess what - we all 
need money to survive. But this is not about operating costs, this is not 
even trying because their profit margin might suffer.

If you want an analogy, imagine a homeless man wanting some help to stand 
up. The drug companies are acting like there is a million dollar fee to do 
it, and so they don't really try at all. Only now are they starting to try 
because the world is start to pressure them. But they never wanted to 
because they might suffer a small setback like getting a dirty hand. If we 
are passing by, most of us will try as hard as we can to help him up, but 
not to the point of breaking our backs. 

I am saying that profit and costs are considerations in making the decision 
on what to research, but when thats your only consideration, not the impact 
it can have on lives - then clearly they are focused only on profits and 
only care about others when they can make profits from it. Don't we have 
doctors and medical researchers to do everything possible to save lives in 
the first place?

comments.author: MrTopGunnar

comments.text:
+MrTopGunnar 
Again, you are saying the exact opposite than what the science says. From 
the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics ( 
http://www.eatright.org/WorkArea/linkit.aspx?LinkIdentifier=id&ItemID=8417)


"Plant protein can meet protein requirements
when a variety of plant
foods is consumed and energy needs
a�re met. Research indicates that an
assortment of plant foods eaten over
the course of a day can provide all
essential amino acids and ensure adequate
nitrogen retention and use in
healthy adults; thus, complementary
proteins do not need to be consumed
at the same meal (8).
[...]
Although some vegan women have
protein intakes that are marginal,
typical protein intakes of lacto-ovovegetarians
and of vegans appear to
meet and exceed requirements (12).
Athletes can also meet their protein
needs on plant-based diets (13)."

"In addition, some studies
show that the ratio of dietary calcium
to protein is a better predictor of bone
health than calcium intake alone.
Typically, this ratio is high in lactoovo-vegetarian
diets and favors bone
health, whereas vegans have a ratio
of calcium to protein that is similar to
or lower than that of nonvegetarians
(39). Many vegans may find it is easier
to meet their calcium needs if calcium-fortified
foods or dietary supplements
are utilized (39)."

"High protein intake, especially animal
protein, can produce increased
calciuria (167,174). Postmenopausal
women with diets high in animal protein
and low in plant protein revealed
a high rate of bone loss and a greatly
increased risk of hip fracture (175).
Although excessive protein intake
may compromise bone health, evidence
exists that low protein intakes
may increase the risk of low bone integrity
(176)."

president. Therefore, his elections only happen every four yours, the last 
one being 2012, and the next one being 2016, not 2014. Four, mind you, not 
two years, four years. As I said before Midterm is not presidential, why 
would he run for something lower than presidential if he is the president? 
I know diseases can reoccur, and that they can be caused by something or 
perhaps someone, but that this conspiracy theory is not a very intelligent 
one. If you know ANYTHING about American politics, it's that Midterms are 
not presidential, and Obama is presidential, so therefore, using direct 
logic, Obama would not be on the Midterm elections because presidential 
elections do not happen until 2016, not 2014, two years after the last one, 
instead of four years as American law states. I would honestly be surprised 
if you were American, please tell me you're not. If you were, how do you 
know so little about our political systems?

comments.text:
Eating bushmeat is relatively common in West Africa, i'm sure many 
thousands of people in the region do that every year. The disease is more 
likely to come from the bat biting a victim in self-defence in the process 
of being caught, or as a result of the meat being undercooked, than from 
properly-prepared bushmeat.

They traced the origin of the outbreak to a small village in Guinea named 
Meliandou, where a little boy first showed symptoms of the disease and 
passed it onto his family. Here's the BBC article if you want to give it a 
read,
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-30199004
comments.author: Merry Machiavelli

comments.text: If it was cooked, I don't think so...
comments.author: NewZero Games

captions.text: In the summer of 1976,

a mysterious epidemic
suddenly struck two central African towns,
killing the majority of its victims.
Medical researchers suspected

the deadly Marburg virus 
to be the culprit.

But what they saw in microscope images
was an entirely new pathogen,

which would be named
after the nearby Ebola river.
Like yellow fever or dengue,

the disease caused by the Ebola virus
is a severe type of hemorrhagic fever.

It begins by attacking 
the immune system's cells
and neutralizing its responses,
allowing the virus to proliferate.

Starting anywhere from two to twenty days
after contraction,
initial symptoms like high temperature,
aching,
and sore throat
resemble those of a typical flu,
but quickly escalate to vomiting,
rashes,
and diarrhea.
And as the virus spreads,

it invades the lymph nodes 
and vital organs,

such as kidneys and liver,
causing them to lose function.

But the virus itself 
is not what kills Ebola victims.

Instead, the mounting cell deaths 
trigger an immune system overload,
known as a cytokine storm,

an explosion of immune responses
that damages blood vessels,
causing both internal and external bleeding.

The excessive fluid loss 
and resulting complications

can be fatal within six to sixteen days
of the first symptoms,
though proper care and rehydration therapy

can significantly reduce 
mortality rates in patients.

Fortunately, 
while Ebola is highly virulent,
several factors limit its contagiousness.

Unlike viruses that proliferate through
small, airborne particles,
Ebola only exists in bodily fluids,
such as saliva,
blood,
mucus,
vomit,
or feces.
In order to spread,

these must be transmitted from 
an infected person into another's body

through passageways such as the eyes,
mouth, or nose.
And because the disease's severity

increases directly along 
with the viral load,

even an infected person 
is unlikely to be contagious
until they have begun to show symptoms.

While Ebola has been shown 
to survive on surfaces for several hours,

and transmission through sneezing
or coughing is theoretically possible,

virtually all known cases of contraction
have been through direct contact
with the severely ill,

with the greatest risk 
posed to medical workers
and friends or relatives of the victims.

This is why,
despite its horrifying effects,

Ebola has been far less deadly overall
than more common infections,
such as measles,
malaria,
or even influenza.
Once an outbreak has been contained,

the virus does not exist 
in the human population
until the next outbreak begins.
But while this is undoubtedly a good thing,
it also makes Ebola difficult to study.

Scientists believe fruit bats 
to be its natural carriers,

but just how it is transmitted to humans
remains unknown.

Furthermore, many of the countries 
where Ebola outbreaks occur
suffer from poor infrastructure and sanitation,
which enables the disease to spread.
And the poverty of these regions,

combined with the relatively low amount
of overall cases

means there is little economic incentive
for drug companies to invest in research.

Though some experimental medicines
have shown promise,

and governments are funding development
of a vaccine,
as of 2014,

the only widespread and effective 
solutions to an Ebola outbreak remain
isolation,
sanitation,
and information.

title: What we know (and don't know) about Ebola - Alex Gendler
